p: The most serious and prevalent type of home air pollution is secondhand or environmental tobacco smoke (ETS). The risk from this indoor pollutant begins in utero. Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with increased infant wheezing ( 56). This risk of respiratory morbidity continues to increase with postnatal parental smoking ( 57). Laws regulating indoor tobacco smoking in one European country were followed by improved quality-of-life scores in a group of asthmatic indoor workers ( 58) and also by a reduction in the overall rate of hospitalizations for childhood asthma ( 59).
